text.p: Following are the main stories in Wednesday's Malaysian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said delegates attending the United Malays National Organisation's (UMNO) general assembly were not compelled to cast their ballots if the candidates were not worthy of their votes. He said he would rather see empty ballot papers than have corrupt and unscrupulous candidates elected.
-- Some 200,000 former Parti Melayu Semangat 46 members, including its president Tengku Razaleigh Hamzah, became UMNO members in a historic ceremony.
-- The government has detected irregularities in the hiring of foreign workers by company officers and is urging chief executives to look into the matter.
-- UMNO President Mahathir Mohamad said elected party leaders can still be dropped from their posts if they are found to have breached party ethics.
-- International Trade and Industry Minister Rafidah Aziz said certain employment agents overseas have been paying recruiting officers of companies in Malaysia to secure jobs for their clients.
-- The Human Resources Ministry has proposed a higher levy for unskilled workers in a move to cut the intake of foreign workers into the country.
-- Malaysia has shot down a proposed declared documentation at the World Trade Organisation aimed at compelling member countries to liberalise their telecommunications industry.
